Writing Prompt: A witch is tired of her two friends always bickering, they are both very well-endowed and often loudly argue about which of them has the better breasts. She has an idea and cast a spell to shut them up. The two friends are transformed into femboys, their boobs shrank to become the firm flat chest of a man, their figure became lankier and andrygenous and their long hair was replaced by a short boyish haircut, followed by their bikinis turning into swim trunks. They are furious at their witch friend at first but she says that she's not turning them back if they don't play with each other. Without being able to querrel about their curves they are able to have fun together for once. Near the end of the day their new bodies feel an unexpected attraction for feminine boys that they never had before and they make out. The day after that they even ask their witch friend to not turn them back at least for now because they want to try dating, the witch is stunned by what she is hearing but is happy to see that her friends are getting along.

Once upon a time, in a quaint riverside town, there lived a trio of friends. Cecilia, the raven-haired witch, and her two enchanting and voluptuous friends, Morgana and Genevieve. As close as the trio appeared, there was one ongoing dispute between Morgana and Genevieve: each felt certain that she had the superior breasts. Their constant bickering seemed not only frivolous but irritating to their kind-hearted witchy friend.

Cecilia had grown tired of their quarrels and wanted her friends to enjoy each other's company, rather than bicker. One day, she had an idea—an ingenious and creative idea! She would cast a spell on her friends to grant them a fresh perspective.

After Morgana and Genevieve arrived at the river for a swim, Cecilia slowly unrolled the scroll containing the incantation she had carefully prepared. With a gentle wave of her hands, she recited the spell.

Immediately, Morgana and Genevieve felt a peculiar sensation. Their voluminous bosoms shrunk to become the firm, flat chest of a man. Their feminine curves faded away, their figures becoming lankier and androgynous. Morgana's fiery red curls and Genevieve's silky blonde locks disappeared, replaced by short, boyish haircuts. To cap it all off, their bikinis morphed into swim trunks.

For a moment, both friends stared at each other in disbelief and frustration, unsure of their new appearances. However, they soon realized that their pointless argument had come to an end. They could no longer compare their physical assets, and as a result, their focus shifted to experiencing their new form.

Recalling Cecilia's words that they should play with each other, Morgana and Genevieve began a friendly game of water volleyball. With every touch of the ball and splash of the river, they started to feel closer than they had in years.

The day eventually came to an end, and the last rays of sunlight cast a golden hue over the idyllic scene. Morgana and Genevieve, left breathless by their afternoon fun, made a surprising discovery. Their bodies, now being femboys, had a newfound attraction to each other. The unexpected connection felt surreal, but their hearts pounded with excitement. It was that moment when they shared their first tentative kiss, discovering an entirely new facet of their relationship.

The next day, Morgana and Genevieve approached Cecilia, their faces glowing with happiness. They asked if she could please delay changing them back - at least for now. They wished to explore the reality of being femboys together, wanting to experience dating for the first time without the constant shadow of their previous quarrel.

Cecilia, bemused but overjoyed at the transformation in their friendship, agreed to their request. As the two new femboys held hands and walked off into the distance, a small, satisfied smile creased her lips. For Cecilia knew that in the end, it wasn't the spell that had created a lasting bond between her two friends; it was their newfound ability to appreciate each other's true beauty in a world that transcended superficial matters. And that, indeed, was a magical transformation.

Hola eres mi asesor de mi trabajo de grado y quiero que busques referencias bibliográficas en formato apa con 5 años de actualidad (estamos en el 2023) y si es posible que me proporciones los links de cada referencia bibliográficas y cada referencia estará ordenado en base al siguiente texto: Presupuesto de Ventas:

Viene a constituir el núcleo de todo el sistema presupuestario y punto de partida para los demás presupuestos. Activa todo el sistema presupuestario de la empresa y, por lo general, proporciona datos por meses, del área ventas. De allí, la trascendental importancia que tiene la actitud de su cálculo y preparación.  

Principio de Consistencia: 

El cual indica que deben utilizarse siempre la misma política, en los procedimientos de contabilidad no deben introducirse cambios constantes, debido a que ello, además de alterar los resultados tiende a confundir al usuario en sus interpretaciones. Asimismo, la consistencia se apoya en el siguiente argumento es necesario contraponer el pesimismo, al optimismo desmedido del dueño y gerente de la institución, la estimación de las ganancias no resultara tan dañina a la organización, como la estimación de sus pérdidas.  


Principio de Determinación Objetiva: 

Establece que la base para registrar los activos y los gastos deben ser la del costo, de modo que los estados financieros y los registros de contabilidad deben reflejar los costos de adquisición, los de las transformaciones en su contraposición a la parte esperada de tales costos.  

Principio del Conservatismo:

Este es uno de los conceptos más importantes, e indica que la institución no debe reflejar beneficios hasta obtenerlos y proveer las posibles pérdidas en el momento en que se presenten. Los ingresos y los gastos deben reflejarse en el momento en que se generan y no en el momento en que se cobran o se pagan.  

Principio de Aplicación en el Tiempo: 

Este principio indica que los valores mostrados en los estados financieros corresponden a un período de tiempo determinado, y que los ingresos y egresos, corresponden al período en que se generaron.  

En resumidas cuentas, para que la contabilidad rinda sus mejores frutos y pueda proporcionar Estados Financieros realmente útiles y confiables, se hace necesario acordar una serie de Principios de Contabilidad. Estos principios, si bien carecen de autoridad formal, apoyan la vigencia en el grado de aceptación generalmente que le dispensen los profesionales de la Contaduría quienes están en el deber de acatarlas y hacerlas cumplir en todas sus intervenciones profesionales.  



Cumplimiento de promesa: 

Significa entregar correcta y oportunamente el servicio acordado. Aunque ambos requisitos (entrega correcta y oportuna) pueden parecer diferentes, los clientes han mencionado que ambos tienen igual importancia, pues provocan su confianza o desconfianza hacia la empresa. En opinión del cliente, la confianza es lo más importante en materia de servicio.  

Gerencia: Toma de Decisiones, 

El modo de pensar del gerente sobre las cosas, las personas y las organizaciones, es un factor crítico para el mejoramiento de la calidad, la productividad y la integración del personal. El centro de la gerencia, es el ser humano, aquél al que se sirve y aquél que sirve, pudiéndose conceptualizar que al que se sirve, se paga un servicio o acude al servicio y espera calidad, y pagará o acudirá con mayor devoción en la medida en que este satisfecho.

上述代码为C++中的文件管理器相关代码，其中包含了多个函数，主要涉及的功能有：

- 发送驱动器列表（SendDriveList）：获取目标机器的驱动器列表并发送给主控端。
- 确认目录存在（MakeSureDirectoryPathExists）：将一个目录路径中所有的目录都创建出来，确保该目录存在。
- 上传文件到远端（UploadToRemote）：从本地上传文件到远端主机。
- 检查上传列表（FixedUploadList）：检查上传列表，确保其中的文件都存在。
- 停止传输（StopTransfer）：在传输文件或目录时，可通过此函数停止传输。
- 发送文件列表（SendFilesList）：获取指定目录下的所有文件列表，将其发送给主控端。
- 删除目录（DeleteDirectory）：从目标机器上删除指定的目录。
- 发送文件大小（SendFileSize）：发送指定文件的文件大小给主控端。
- 发送文件数据（SendFileData）：发送指定文件的数据给主控端。
- 创建目录（CreateFolder）：在目标机器中创建一个新的目录。
- 重命名文件（Rename）：重命名指定文件/目录。
- 发送令牌（SendToken）：向主控端发送一个令牌。
- 创建本地接收文件（CreateLocalRecvFile）：在本地指定路径中创建一个接收文件。
- 设置传输模式（SetTransferMode）：设置传输模式。
- 获取文件数据（GetFileData）：获取指定文件的数据。
- 写本地接收文件（WriteLocalRecvFile）：向本地接收文件写入数据。
- 上传下一个文件（UploadNext）：上传下一个文件。
- 打开文件（OpenFile）：打开指定的文件并显示。
- 以及一些成员变量，例如上传列表、传输模式、当前正在处理的文件名等。

这些函数通过组合可以实现文件的上传下载、目录的

Before his reincarnation, during the days when he was Michael Shin.

His dribbling ability was among the best in the world.

He was a player with one of the highest successful dribble rates globally, often breaking through the opposition's defense, fulfilling the role of a crack player.

He can no longer play the game of mocking defenders with just his speed.

However, he had regained much of his past dribbling ability.

That alone was enough to break through Atletico Madrid's defense.

Shin Jaewook was confident of that.

"I can definitely do it."

During a counterattack created by cutting off Atletico Madrid's offense.

The opponent was a team considered to have the best defense in the world at the time.

But there was no hesitation in Shin Jaewook's advance.

Thwack! Tap!

He kicked the ball forward briskly, increasing his speed.

Naturally, Atletico Madrid's defenders saw these openings.

"Cut him off!"

"His dribble is long! Intercept it!"

"Block him right away!"

The shouts of Atletico Madrid's players erupted.

Joao Miranda, who was running closest to Shin Jaewook, charged at him.

Joao Miranda was a player known for his intelligent defense using his good head.

His ability was so great that he played as a starting defender for Atletico Madrid alongside his teammate Diego Godin.

But now, he showed an uncharacteristic eagerness.

He couldn't resist going for the obvious gap in Shin Jaewook's defense.

— Joao Miranda is charging at player Shin Jaewook!

Joao Miranda's movement to extend his leg was sharp.

However, the problem was that Shin Jaewook had anticipated it.

'The tackle was too hasty. I won't fall for such a tackle.'

Shin Jaewook pushed the ball to the opposite side just as Joao Miranda stretched out his leg.

At the same time, he moved in the direction he had pushed the ball.

— Wow! Shin Jaewook has bypassed Joao Miranda with a neat dribble!

— Atletico Madrid is in crisis! Joao Miranda's tackle was too hasty!

With a defender bypassed in a situation that allowed a counterattack, a significant gap opened in Atletico Madrid's defense.

Shin Jaewook thoroughly exploited that gap.

— The choice of direction for Shin Jaewook's dribble is excellent! This player is so intelligent!

— It's as if he's looking down from above on the field, finding the opponent's weaknesses! How wide is Shin Jaewook's field of vision?

His movement, penetrating only through the opponent's weaknesses with perfect judgment, was refreshing to watch and didn't cause any frustration for the viewers.

Of course, for the defenders who had to block him, it was a dreadful movement.

Swoosh! Tap!

As Shin Jaewook penetrated the space created by Joao Miranda, Atletico Madrid's goalkeeper Courtois left his goal and rushed out.

It was an action to try to steal the ball from the attacker or, at the very least, reduce the shooting angle.

However, this action had a significant weakness.

It was very vulnerable to chip shots.

— Goooooal! It's a goal by Shin Jaewook! He's showing his abilities even in the Champions League final!

— Such a calm finish! He saw Courtois coming out and executed a precise chip shot! That's a true striker!

— Every decision was perfect! The dribbling and shooting were fantastic! After this match, Shin Jaewook's reputation will rise even higher, won't it?

— He's already receiving love calls from many teams, right? Ha ha! If this continues, Shin Jaewook's agent will have a lot of work to do.

— Bayern Munich must be feeling anxious, right? They want to keep Shin Jaewook, but he's playing too well!

Shin Jaewook was a player who could freely execute chip shots, and he easily scored a goal by shooting over Courtois's height.

'I did it. Thanks to <PRESIDIO_ANONYMIZED_PERSON> rushing in hastily, it was easier than I thought.'

It was a satisfying goal.

It was close to the best movement he could make with his current physical condition.

'Let's not rush anymore.'

Even though he scored, Shin Jaewook didn't run towards the ball as usual.

He stretched out his arms towards his approaching teammates and shouted loudly.

신재욱의 선제골로 1 대 0 스코어가 된 이후.

러시아 선수들의 머릿속엔 빨리 만회 골을 넣겠다는 마음이 가득했다.

이들은 오늘 한국에게 질 생각이 없었다.

무조건 이겨서 16강행을 노릴 생각이었다.

그래서 경기가 시작된 직후에도 빠르게 공을 돌리며 기회를 만들려고 했다.

그렇게 생각했었다.

갑자기 신재욱이 달려들기 전까지는.

― 어어? 신재욱 선수가 알렉산드르 코코린 선수에게 달려듭니다!

러시아의 공격수 코코린.

그는 발재간에 자신이 있는 선수였다.

때문에, 웬만하면 공을 뺏기지 않을 자신감이 있었다.

그래서일까?

덤벼드는 신재욱을 보고도 동료에게 공을 넘기지 않았다.

본능적으로 직접 탈압박을 시도했다.

그게 코코린의 실수였다.



― 뺏었습니다! 신재욱 선수가 전매특허인 슬라이딩 태클로 알렉산드르 코코린 선수의 공을 뺏어냈습니다!

― 여지없네요! 코코린 선수는 기술이 좋은 선수인데, 신재욱 선수의 태클에 걸리니 어쩔 도리가 없네요!

― 스트라이커이면서도 세계 최고 수준의 슬라이딩 태클 능력을 지닌 신재욱 선수입니다!

― 이러면 러시아로서는 기분이 나쁠 수밖에 없죠! 뭔가를 시도해보기도 전에 뺏겼거든요?



신재욱은 더 나아가지 않았다.

공을 뺏자마자 바로 근처에 있던 이청영에게 패스했다.

이청영은 유럽에서도 통할 정도로 기술이 좋은 선수였고, 지금도 그 능력을 보여줬다.



― 이청영 선수의 좋은 탈압박입니다! 오늘 움직임이 가벼워 보이는데요?

― 이청영이 기석용에게 공을 넘깁니다. 천천히 풀어나가려는 것 같네요.

― 급할 필요가 없죠. 선제골을 넣었으니까요.



이청영이 좋은 움직임으로 러시아의 압박을 이겨내며 기석용에게 공을 연결했고.

기석용은 근처에 있던 김국영에게 패스했다.

여유가 느껴지는 패스 플레이였다.

그러나 러시아의 압박은 점점 더 강해졌다.

자연스레 한국 선수들에게서도 여유가 사라졌다.

러시아의 압박을 쉽게 이겨낼 수 있는 선수는 한국대표팀에 많지 않았다.

물론 몇몇 선수는 달랐다.

여전히 여유가 넘쳤다.



― 손훈민 선수! 공을 잘 지켜냈습니다! 무리하진 않네요! 손훈민, 이택현에게 패스합니다.

― 이택현 선수, 오늘 컨디션이 굉장히 좋아 보였죠? 조금 전에 신재욱 선수의 골을 어시스트 하기도 했고요.



손훈민과 이택현.

이들은 러시아 선수들에게서 압박을 받으면서도 자신들의 플레이를 했다.

그리고 신재욱 역시 마찬가지였다.



― 이택현 선수의 좋은 드리블입니다!



압박을 벗어난 이택현이 속도를 높였다.

그는 앞으로 달리며 신재욱에게 공을 넘겼다. 그러나 달리는 것은 멈추지 않았다.

그리고 신재욱은 굴러오는 공을 툭― 밀어냈다.

앞으로 달려가는 이택현을 향한 원터치 패스였다.



― 오오오! 좋은 플레이입니다! 신재욱 선수와 이택현 선수가 또다시 훌륭한 호흡을 보여줍니다!

― 이택현이 엄청난 속도로 파고듭니다!



신재욱의 패스는 절묘했다.

이택현이 달리는 속도에 정확히 맞춘 패스였고, 방향과 강도도 완벽했다.



― 이택현 선수가 공을 잡아냈습니다!



이택현은 공을 잡았다.

워낙 좋은 패스였기에 어렵지 않게 받아낸 것이었고, 곧바로 바디페인팅까지 사용했다.

들어오는 압박을 피하기 위한 움직임이었다.



휘익! 휙!



덤벼들던 러시아의 수비수는 이택현의 바디페인팅에 속아서 중심을 잃었다.

동시에 이택현에겐 공간이 생겼다.

슈팅하거나 드리블을 할 수 있는 공간.

이때, 이택현은 드리블을 선택했다.

이미 페널티박스에 걸친 위치였는데, 이제는 페널티박스 안으로 들어가며 골키퍼와의 거리를 좁혔다.

물론 그러자 다른 수비수가 덤벼들었다.

무시하기엔 위협적인 움직임이었다. 슈팅을 때릴 각도 사라졌다.

만약 슈팅을 때리고 싶으면 수비수를 제쳐야만 가능해지는 상황이었다.

그러나 이택현은 애초에 슈팅할 생각이 없었다.

더 깊게 들어간 이유도 수비수들의 시선을 끌기 위해서였다.



툭!



이택현은 뒤꿈치를 이용해 공을 뒤로 보냈다.

정확히는 왼쪽 대각선 뒤였다.



“재욱쓰! 이 정도면 충분하지?”



좋은 자리를 잡고 있던 신재욱에게 흘려주는 패스.

신재욱으로서는 편안하게 슈팅을 때릴 기회가 만들어졌다.



“어, 충분해.”



그렇게 중얼거리며, 신재욱은 공을 때려냈다.

왼발로 공을 강하게 감아 찼다. 골키퍼가 오른쪽으로 치우쳐 있는 걸 보고 골대 상단 왼쪽을 노린 슈팅이었다.



퍼어엉!



힘이 제대로 실렸고, 궤적도 깔끔했다.

골대의 오른쪽에 가깝게 위치하던 골키퍼가 막아낼 수 없는 슈팅이었다.



― 우오오옷! 들어갔습니다! 신재욱 선수의 두 번째 골이 터졌습니다! 이게 신재욱이죠!

― 신재욱 선수와 이택현 선수의 호흡이 다시 한번 빛났습니다! 바이에른 뮌헨의 천재 듀오는 러시아의 수비수들이 감당하기엔 너무 강력하네요!



이택현의 어시스트를 받은 신재욱의 골.

스코어는 2 대 0이 되었고.

한국대표팀 선수들은 열광하며 신재욱과 이택현을 둘러쌌다.



“이 예쁜 자식들! 둘이 아주 다 해 먹는구만!”

“잘해도 너무 잘하는 거 아니야? 아주 괴물들이야!”

“흐흐흐흐! 러시아 애들 멘탈 나갔다! 봐봐! 얼굴 보면 영혼이 날아갔잖아.”

“택현아 너는 어떻게 거기서 백힐을 하냐? 재욱이랑 너는 서로 텔레파시라도 통하는 거야, 뭐야?”

“대단한 놈들이야. 역시 천재들은 다르다니까?”



실시간으로 경기를 지켜보던 한국 축구팬들 역시 자리에서 벌떡 일어나며 기뻐했다.



└ 골!!!!!!!!!!!! 터졌다!!!!!!!!

└ 이게 한국 축구 맞아……? 왜케 잘하지?;;;;; 내가 알던 거랑은 너무 다른데……?

└ 신재욱이랑 이택현이 한국 국대의 퀄리티를 3단계 정도는 높여놓은 느낌이야. 진짜 개잘한다ㄷㄷㄷㄷ

└ 러시아 수비수들이 못하는 건가? 이택현이랑 신재욱을 아예 못 막네?

└ 재욱이랑 택현이가 못해 보이게 만드는 거지. 얘네 클래스가 그만큼 높은 거야.

└ 위에 말이 맞는 듯. 러시아가 못하는 게 아니고, 그냥 신재욱이랑 이택현이 잘하는 거 같아.

└ 신재욱은 차는 족족 들어가네? 얘 결정력 사기 수준인데?

└ 분데스리가 2시즌 연속 득점왕이잖아. 신재욱 결정력은 원래 좋았어.



러시아 국가대표팀의 분위기는 매우 안 좋았다.

선수들의 얼굴에 흐르던 자신감은 어느새 사라졌고, 서로의 잘못을 끄집어내며 고성을 주고받았다.

이런 러시아의 좋지 못한 분위기는 경기가 재개된 이후에도 나아지지 않았다.



― 러시아의 움직임이 좋지 않은데요? 지금은 글루샤코프 선수가 좀 더 전진해서 공을 받아줄 필요가 있어 보입니다! 그리고 사메도프 선수도 너무 공을 끌고 있어요! 이미 2번의 턴오버를 했거든요? 사메도프 선수는 조금 더 빠르게 볼 처리를 해야 할 것 같습니다!



러시아의 공격은 무뎌졌다.

경기 초반부터 힘을 실었던 중원 싸움에서도 한국에게 크게 밀리고 있었다.

자연스레 기회는 한국에게 찾아왔다.



― 손훈민 선수가 코너킥을 얻어냈습니다! 한국의 분위기가 매우 좋습니다!

― 기석용 선수가 코너킥을 준비하네요. 이 선수, 킥력이 매우 좋은 선수죠!



킥의 정확도가 뛰어난 기석용이 경기장 코너에서 코너킥을 찼다.



퍼어엉!



강하게 감아 찬 공이 러시아의 페널티박스 안으로 휘어져 들어갔다.

위협적인 궤적이었다.

이때, 페널티박스 안에 있던 선수들이 몸을 띄웠다.

그중 가장 좋은 위치에 있던 선수는 신재욱이었다.

신재욱은 기석용이 보낸 공의 궤적을 잘 예측했고, 좋은 타이밍에 몸을 띄우기까지 했다.

190cm의 수비수 바실리 베레주츠키가 바로 옆에서 방해를 해왔지만, 신재욱은 경합에서 전혀 밀리지 않았다.

점프력도 바실리 베레주츠키보다 더 뛰어났다.



터엉!



신재욱이 날아오는 공을 머리로 찍어 내렸다.

힘이 제대로 실린 헤더.

공은 대각선 밑으로 떨어져 내렸다.

러시아의 골키퍼가 당황하며 손을 휘저었다. 날아오는 공의 궤적을 예상하지 못했기에 나온 반응이었다.

운이 좋으면 공을 건드릴 수도 있었겠지만, 러시아의 골키퍼 아킨페프에겐 운이 따르지 않았다.

그의 손은 공을 건드리지 못했다.



투웅!



잔디 위로 떨어진 공이 다시 튕기며 러시아의 골대 안으로 들어갔다.



― 고오오오오오오올! 신재욱 선수가 엄청난 헤더로 세 번째 골을 기록했습니다!

― 해트트릭이네요! 신재욱 선수! 러시아를 무자비하게 무너뜨리고 있습니다! 수준이 다르네요! 정말 이 선수는 수준이 달라요!

― 신재욱 선수는 정말 대단한데요? 러시아의 수비수들을 너무 쉽게 상대하고 있어요! 더군다나 방금 상대한 바실리 베레주츠키 선수는 못하는 선수가 아니거든요? 러시아 리그의 강팀 CSKA 모스크바에서 매우 좋은 수비를 보여주는 선수인데, 신재욱 선수가 공중볼에서까지 압도해버리네요!

― 지난 2013/14시즌부터는 공중볼 경합 능력도 빠르게 좋아지면서, 결국 시즌 막바지엔 웬만한 수비수들은 전부 이겨버리지 않았습니까? 그리고 챔피언스리그에서도 좋은 공중볼 경합 능력을 보여줬었고요.

― 해외 축구팬들은 신재욱 선수를 완성형 스트라이커라고 말한다던데, 정말 완성형 스트라이커가 맞는 것 같네요. 발과 머리를 모두 잘 쓰며, 언제 어디서든 골을 넣어주니까요!



3 대 0.

이기고 있는 팀은 승리를 확신하게 되는 스코어였다.

반대로 지고 있는 팀은 패배를 직감하게 되는 스코어였다.

그리고 해트트릭을 기록하며 이런 상황을 만들어낸 신재욱은 흥분한 동료들에게 축하를 받고 있었다.



“우오오오! 이 미친놈아! 해트트릭이라니! 으하하핫! 축하한다 진짜로!”

“해트트릭을 해? 월드컵에서? 재욱아! 내가 살면서 너 같은 괴물을 또 볼 수 있을까?”

“골 축하한다! 3골을 넣을 줄은 몰랐는데, 역시 대단해!”

“재욱아, 고맙다. 네 덕에 어시스트 하나 올렸어.”

“대단하다 정말! 거기서 경합을 이기고 헤더 골을 넣어버리네!”



같은 시각.

실시간으로 경기를 보던 한국 축구팬들 역시도 흥분하고 있었다.

conversation.text: Please provide a comprehensive list of documents a cybersecurity needs to have in order to be compliant with the NIST

In order to be compliant with the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) cybersecurity standards, there are several important documents that a cybersecurity program needs to have. Here is a comprehensive list:

1. Risk Management Framework (RMF) Documentation:
   - System Security Plan (SSP)
   - Security Assessment Plan (SAP)
   - Security Assessment Report (SAR)
   - Plan of Actions and Milestones (POA&M)
   - Continuous Monitoring Strategy

2. Policies and Procedures:
   - Information Security Policy
   - Incident Response Policy
   - Risk Management Policy
   - Access Control Policy
   - Configuration Management Policy
   - Contingency Planning Policy
   - Media Protection Policy
   - Physical and Environmental Security Policy

3. Privacy Documents:
   - Privacy Impact Assessment (PIA)
   - Privacy Policy
   - Data Retention and Destruction Policy

4. System Documentation:
   - System Architecture Diagrams
   - Network Diagrams
   - Hardware and Software Inventory
   - Configuration Management Database (CMDB)
   - System Configuration Baseline

5. Incident Response Documentation:
   - Incident Response Plan
   - Incident Response Playbooks
   - Incident Reporting Templates
   - Evidence Collection Guidelines

6. Security Training and Awareness Materials:
   - Security Awareness Training Plan
   - Training Materials and Modules
   - Phishing Simulation Results

7. Vulnerability Management Documentation:
   - Vulnerability Assessment Reports
   - Patch Management Plan
   - Change Management Procedures

8. Audit and Compliance Documentation:
   - Audit Plan
   - Audit Reports
   - Compliance Checklists

9. Business Continuity/Disaster Recovery (BC/DR) Documents:
   - Business Impact Analysis (BIA)
   - Business Continuity Plan (BCP)
   - Disaster Recovery Plan (DRP)
   - Testing and Exercising Documentation

10. System and User Authentication Documents:
    - Authentication Policy
    - Multi-factor Authentication (MFA) Implementation Plan
    - User Account and Password Management Policy

11. Security Incident and Event Logging Documents:
    - Security Logging and Monitoring Policy
    - Log Review Procedures
    - Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) Reports

It's important to note that this list may vary depending on the specific NIST cybersecurity framework being followed (e.g., NIST SP 800-53, NIST CSF) and the organization's individual requirements. Additionally, periodic updates, revisions, and reviews of these documents are necessary to maintain compliance with evolving cybersecurity standards and best practices.
What would be the best NIST CSF guidance to use for a cybersecurity service provider?

For a cybersecurity service provider, the best NIST CSF (Cybersecurity Framework) guidance to use would be the NIST Special Publication 800-171. This publication specifically focuses on protecting Controlled Unclassified Information (CUI) in non-federal systems and organizations.

NIST SP 800-171 provides a framework of security requirements and controls that a service provider needs to implement in order to ensure the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of CUI. It covers a wide range of security areas, including access control, incident response, risk assessment, contingency planning, physical security, and system integrity. By following this guidance, a cybersecurity service provider can demonstrate their commitment to protecting sensitive information and maintaining a secure environment.

In addition to NIST SP 800-171, a cybersecurity service provider should also consider referencing other relevant NIST publications such as:

1. NIST SP 800-53: Security and Privacy Controls for Federal Information Systems and Organizations - This publication provides a comprehensive set of security controls that can be used as a baseline for protecting information systems and is widely recognized as a valuable resource.

2. NIST SP 800-37: Guide for Applying the Risk Management Framework to Federal Information Systems - This guide outlines the risk management process and provides detailed steps for implementing the NIST Risk Management Framework (RMF), which is crucial for assessing and managing cybersecurity risks.

To ensure compliance with ISO 27001, the international standard for information security management systems (ISMS), a bank can follow a framework that encompasses several key steps and components. Here's an outline of the framework:

1. Establish the Context:
   - Define the information security objectives and scope aligned with the bank's business goals.
   - Identify and involve relevant stakeholders, including management, employees, and customers.
   - Conduct a risk assessment to understand the bank's security risks and vulnerabilities.

2. Leadership and Management Commitment:
   - Obtain strong management commitment for information security and assign roles and responsibilities.
   - Define a governance structure and establish an Information Security Management System (ISMS) team.
   - Develop and communicate the bank's information security policies, objectives, and procedures.

3. Risk Assessment and Treatment:
   - Identify and assess information security risks using a systematic approach.
   - Determine the level of risk acceptance and select appropriate risk treatment measures.
   - Implement controls to mitigate identified risks, considering ISO 27001's Annex A control objectives.

4. Documentation and Implementation:
   - Develop the necessary documentation, including an Information Security Policy, procedures, and work instructions.
   - Implement the controls identified during the risk treatment process.
   - Communicate and train employees on their roles and responsibilities for information security.

5. Monitoring and Evaluation:
   - Establish a process for ongoing monitoring and measurement of the ISMS effectiveness.
   - Conduct internal audits to assess compliance with ISO 27001 requirements.
   - Perform regular reviews of the ISMS performance and identify areas for improvement.

6. Continuous Improvement:
   - Implement a corrective action process to address non-conformities and ensure continual improvement.
   - Conduct management reviews to evaluate the effectiveness and suitability of the ISMS.
   - Stay updated with emerging threats, vulnerabilities, and changes in legal/regulatory requirements.

7. Certification:
   - Engage an independent certification body for an ISO 27001 audit to confirm compliance.
   - Continually maintain and improve the ISMS to ensure ongoing compliance and readiness for future audits.

Remember, ISO 27001 implementation can be complex and time-consuming, requiring involvement from multiple stakeholders. It is recommended to engage information security professionals and consultants with expertise in ISO 27001 to ensure a thorough and successful implementation of the standard in a banking environment.

Introduction to the SSP in the context of a cybersecurity company:

The System Security Plan (SSP) is a crucial document that outlines the cybersecurity controls and measures implemented within a cybersecurity company's systems and infrastructure. It serves as a comprehensive reference guide for understanding the security posture of the company's assets and the protection of sensitive information.

The SSP plays a vital role in ensuring the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of the company's systems and data, as well as in demonstrating compliance with relevant industry standards and regulatory requirements. By documenting the implemented security controls, the SSP provides transparency and accountability, allowing stakeholders to understand how the company safeguards its assets and manages cyber risks.

The purpose of the SSP is multi-fold:

1. Providing an Overview: The SSP offers an introductory section that provides a high-level overview of the document's purpose, scope, and objectives. It sets the context for the rest of the plan by outlining the goals of the cybersecurity company in terms of security measures and the protection of critical assets.

2. Defining Responsibility: The SSP designates the system owner, highlighting their accountability for ensuring the security and appropriate management of the company's systems. It also identifies the system administrators and key personnel responsible for implementing and maintaining the security controls outlined in the plan.

3. Describing the System: The SSP provides a comprehensive description of the system(s) covered in the plan, including the architecture, components, functionalities, and interactions. This section ensures that readers have a clear understanding of the system's design and its associated security considerations.

4. Demonstrating Compliance: The SSP demonstrates the cybersecurity company's commitment to meeting industry standards, regulatory requirements, and best practices. It highlights the security controls implemented based on established frameworks such as NIST, ISO 27001, or specific industry-specific guidelines. This allows auditors, customers, and partners to assess the company's adherence to security standards and make informed decisions.

5. Guiding Decision-Making: The SSP serves as a guiding document for the cybersecurity company's ongoing decision-making processes related to security. It helps identify gaps in the security posture, vulnerabilities, and areas requiring improvements or enhancements. Recommendations and actions documented within the SSP influence future security investments and initiatives.

6. Assisting Incident Response: The SSP provides an overview of incident response procedures and contact information for reporting security incidents. It assists the cybersecurity company in effectively mitigating and responding to security breaches or other security-related events, ensuring a quick and coordinated response to minimize the impact.

In summary, the SSP serves as a critical document that outlines the cybersecurity controls, responsibilities, and measures in place within a cybersecurity company. It helps demonstrate compliance, informs decision-making, and guides incident response efforts, ultimately fostering a secure and resilient environment for both the company and its stakeholders.

Write a step by step guide on how to set up and get ready for a session of Pair programming. This should include things such as setting a clear expectation and goal for the session. Having a clear idea of the problem to solve. An appropriate place to hold a session which includes considerations for seating screen visibility, and noise levels. And agree on a break schedule if the pair session is expected to last several hours. Especially if it's a remote  pairing. Step one. Step two. And so on and so forth

Step 1: Define the objective Before starting the pair programming session, establish a clear expectation and goal. Discuss the specific problem to solve or the feature to develop with your partner to ensure both participants are aligned.

Step 2: Choose a location Select an appropriate place to hold the session, considering factors such as seating, screen visibility, and noise levels. Make sure the environment is comfortable and conducive to focused work.

Step 3: Set up the workspace Ensure that both participants have access to the necessary tools, such as computers, keyboards, and relevant software. If working remotely, set up a screen-sharing application and communication tool, like video conferencing or instant messaging.

Step 4: Review roles and responsibilities Discuss the roles of driver and navigator, making sure both participants understand their responsibilities. This will help establish a smooth workflow and encourage effective collaboration.

Step 5: Establish a break schedule Agree on a break schedule, especially if the pair programming session is expected to last several hours. Regular breaks can help maintain focus and prevent burnout.

Step 6: Set a timer for role-switching Decide on a time interval for switching roles between driver and navigator, such as every 20-30 minutes. Use a timer to ensure regular role rotation, promoting shared understanding and balanced contributions.

Step 7: Start the session Begin the pair programming session by tackling the task at hand. Remember to communicate openly, share knowledge, and provide constructive feedback throughout the process.

Step 8: Reflect and improve After the session, take the time to reflect on the experience. Discuss what worked well and what could be improved for future sessions, and use this feedback to enhance your pair programming practices.

Pair Programming Best Practices
Author: Carlos Rey, Mar 2023

Welcome to the wonderful world of pair programming, where collaboration and knowledge sharing come together to create a productive and enjoyable software development experience!

In pair programming, the roles of driver and navigator are crucial for ensuring effective collaboration and productivity. These distinct roles enable the participants to balance their contributions and share knowledge throughout the coding process. By understanding and embodying their respective roles, developers can optimize their pair programming experience for better results and growth.

Pair programming generates more diverse solutions to problems because:

Collaboration: Two developers working together can bring unique perspectives and experiences to the table, encouraging a wider range of ideas and approaches.
Continuous feedback: The real-time exchange of feedback between the driver and navigator allows for quicker identification of potential issues, resulting in more effective problem-solving.
Knowledge sharing: Pair programming facilitates the transfer of skills and expertise between participants, promoting creative solutions through the combination of their individual strengths and experiences.
The Roles
Driver - WRITE:
W - Write the code, focusing on syntax and implementation.
R - Relay your thought process to your partner for better collaboration.
I - Integrate the navigator's suggestions and feedback.
T - Talk through questions and uncertainties to maintain open dialogue.
E - Exchange roles with the navigator when needed, promoting shared learning.
Navigator - GUIDE:
G - Give guidance and suggestions to improve the code.
U - Understand the bigger picture and how the task fits into the project.
I - Invite open dialogue by encouraging questions and shared thoughts.
D - Detect potential issues and offer solutions.
E - Engage as the driver when necessary, demonstrating ideas or assisting with tasks.
Before getting started:
Preparing the pair programming session before starting it is crucial for ensuring a smooth and productive workflow. A well-planned session helps participants align their goals, minimize distractions, and maintain focus, ultimately leading to better results and an enjoyable collaboration experience. A good pair programmer is one who PREPARES:

P - Plan the objective (Define the objective)
R - Ready the location (Choose a location)
E - Equip the workspace (Set up the workspace)
P - Position roles (Review roles and responsibilities)
A - Arrange breaks (Establish a break schedule)
R - Rotate regularly (Set a timer for role-switching)
E - Engage in collaboration (Start the session)
S - Strengthen the process (Reflect and improve)
Running the session:
Keeping track of the aspects mentioned in the CONNECT mnemonic is essential for maintaining effective communication and collaboration during the pair programming session. By focusing on these elements, developers can maximize productivity, foster a positive working environment, and enhance their overall learning experience.

C - Communicate openly (Share thoughts and ideas)
O - Offer constructive feedback (Focus on the code, not the person)
N - Nurture collaboration (Support each other's learning)
N - Navigate challenges (Tackle obstacles together)
E - Embrace diverse solutions (Explore various approaches)
C - Check alignment (Ensure goals and expectations remain aligned)
T - Track progress (Monitor the session's effectiveness and make adjustments)
---

She proposes that they focus their combined forces on Daenerys and Jon Snow, and once they have been defeated, she will allow the Night King to expand his domain in the North.

The Night King, intrigued by Cersei's ambition and cunning, accepts her proposal. He understands that Cersei's hatred for her enemies is so strong that she is willing to make a pact with the embodiment of death itself. This alliance is sealed through a dark and ancient magic that binds their fates together.

As the final battle approaches, Cersei and the Night King secretly communicate through the weirwood network, coordinating their strategies and laying traps for their mutual enemies. While the living believe they are fighting a united front against the dead, Cersei and the Night King prepare to unleash a devastating betrayal that could change the fate of Westeros forever.
don't keep me guessing...describe the betrayal

As Jon Snow, Daenerys Targaryen, and their combined forces prepare to face the Night King and his army of the dead, they remain unaware of the treacherous alliance between Cersei and the Night King. Trusting that Cersei will send her forces to help in the fight against the White Walkers, they focus their strategy on defeating the Night King, believing that the realm will unite against this common enemy.

The day of the final battle arrives, and the armies of the living gather at King's Landing, expecting to be joined by the forces of the Iron Throne. However, as the battle commences, it becomes clear that Cersei's forces are nowhere to be found. Instead, they remain hidden within the walls of King's Landing, ready to execute Cersei's plan.

As the armies of the living and the dead clash in a brutal and chaotic battle, the Night King strategically targets key commanders and heroes amongst the living forces, striking them down with his icy touch. With each fallen hero, the living forces become more disorganized and demoralized.

In the midst of the chaos, Cersei gives the signal for her forces to emerge from King's Landing, but instead of joining the battle against the Night King, they turn on the already weakened forces of Jon and Daenerys. The unsuspecting allies are struck from behind, as the Golden Company and the Lannister forces slaughter them mercilessly.

With their ranks thinning and their commanders falling, the remaining forces of the living are caught between the relentless army of the dead and Cersei's traitorous soldiers. The betrayal is so unexpected and devastating that it leaves Jon and Daenerys reeling, struggling to maintain any semblance of control over the battlefield.

The shock of the betrayal spreads throughout the living forces, sowing fear and desperation. In this moment, the Night King and Cersei's alliance seems unstoppable, and the fate of Westeros hangs in the balance.

However, as the living forces falter, Jon and Daenerys find renewed determination to save their people and defeat their enemies, no matter the cost. How does Arya's shape shifting abilities factor into the final conflict?

As the final conflict rages on and the living forces struggle against the combined threat of the Night King and Cersei's betrayal, Arya Stark becomes a crucial factor in turning the tide of the battle. Does she somehow learn to shapeshift into a white walker?

She must use her entire arsenal of knowledge and skills acquired as a Faceless Man to navigate this unprecedented challenge.

Successfully donning the face of the White Walker, Arya is able to infiltrate their ranks. She also discovers key vulnerabilities within the army of the dead that she can exploit to aid the living forces.

As she navigates the Night King's forces, Arya uses her knowledge and stealth to undermine their efforts, secretly destroying their weapons and eliminating strategic targets. Her actions create confusion and disarray, weakening the Night King's grip on his army.

In the end, Arya's ability to shapeshift into a White Walker plays a pivotal role in the final conflict. As the dust settles and the survivors regroup, Bran's role in the final conflict is recognized as crucial to their ultimate victory. Write the dialog for the exchange between Daenerys and Jon as Daenerys decides to relinquish her pursuit of the throne.

Daenerys and Jon stand together amidst the ruins of King's Landing, gazing upon the devastation caused by the dragons and the war. The weight of their choices and the consequences of their actions hang heavy in the air.

Daenerys: (sighs) I never wanted this, Jon. I wanted to break the wheel, to free the people from the chains of tyranny. But look at what I've done... I've only brought more death and suffering.

Jon: (gently) You can still make a difference, Dany. You have the power to change things for the better. You don't need the Iron Throne to do that.

Daenerys: (hesitates) I've spent my entire life chasing the throne, believing it was my destiny to rule the Seven Kingdoms. But perhaps... perhaps my true purpose lies elsewhere.

Jon: (nods) The realm needs healing and unity now more than ever. We can work together, help the people rebuild their lives and forge a new path for Westeros.

Daenerys: (looking at Jon with determination) You're right. The Iron Throne has only ever brought pain and strife. I will not be the queen who sits on a throne forged from the swords of the fallen. I will be the queen who stands beside her people, guiding them towards a brighter future.

Jon: (smiles) I will stand with you, Dany. Together, we can bring peace to the realm and ensure that the sacrifices made by so many were not in vain.

Daenerys: (smiles back) Thank you, Jon. Together, we will build a new Westeros, one that is worthy of the people who call it home.

As Daenerys and Jon stand united, their shared vision for a better Westeros begins to take shape. They turn away from the wreckage of the Iron Throne and walk side by side, ready to face the challenges ahead and forge a new destiny for their people.
Describe the closing scene

The sun sets over the horizon, casting a warm golden light over the ruins of King's Landing as the people gather to witness the dawn of a new era. The Iron Throne lies destroyed, a symbol of the old ways now reduced to molten metal and twisted steel. In its place, a round table stands at the center of the gathering, surrounded by representatives from each of the Great Houses of Westeros.

Daenerys Targaryen and Jon Snow, hand in hand, address the crowd. Their voices carry the hope of a united realm and the promise of a better future. As they speak of unity, compassion, and justice, the people listen, their faces reflecting a mixture of awe, relief, and cautious optimism.

Around the table, familiar faces like Sansa Stark, Arya Stark, Gendry Baratheon, Tyrion Lannister, Yara Greyjoy, and Samwell Tarly take their seats, ready to participate in the new council that will govern Westeros. They represent not only their respective houses but also the diverse people of the realm, brought together by the shared experience of war, loss, and survival.

As the camera pulls back, the haunting ruins of King's Landing are juxtaposed with the determined faces of the council members, symbolizing the long journey of healing and rebuilding that lies ahead. The scene fades to black, leaving the audience with a sense of hope and the understanding that the story of Westeros, though changed, will continue to unfold in the hearts and minds of those who inhabit it.

The closing scene marks the end of an era and the beginning of a new chapter in the history of Westeros. It serves as a testament to the resilience of the human spirit and the power of unity and collaboration in the face of adversity.

The Night King's demise, coupled with Arya's sacrifice, provides a turning point that unites the once-divided forces of Westeros. The experience of fighting a common enemy creates a newfound understanding and camaraderie among the surviving characters, setting the stage for a more hopeful and cooperative future.

In this version of the ending, the Night King plays a more prominent role in the conclusion, and his defeat serves as a catalyst for the unification of Westeros and the establishment of the new council, ultimately paving the way for the hopeful ending described earlier.
It seems like there should have been some devastating new power that he unleashes as part of the final battle. Describe that power and how Jon overcomes it.

As the final battle against the Night King and his army of the dead reaches its climax, it becomes clear that the Night King has been hiding a devastating new power. He raises his arms, and the sky turns dark, swirling with ominous clouds. Suddenly, an intense blizzard engulfs the battlefield, accompanied by powerful winds, freezing temperatures, and disorienting snowstorms.

This new power amplifies the Night King's control over the dead, allowing him to resurrect fallen soldiers from both sides of the conflict at an alarming rate. The battlefield quickly becomes a chaotic and terrifying scene, as friends and allies are forced to confront the reanimated corpses of their fallen comrades.

Jon Snow and the united forces of Westeros struggle to maintain their ground against this overwhelming and relentless assault. In the midst of the chaos, Jon realizes that the Night King must be stopped at all costs, or the world will be plunged into an eternal winter.

Determined to end the Night King's reign of terror, Jon Snow rallies his closest allies, including Daenerys and her dragon, Drogon, to launch a daring and desperate assault on the Night King's position. As they approach, Jon leaps from Drogon's back and engages the Night King in a fierce battle, their swords clashing amidst the blinding snowstorm.

During the intense duel, Jon's connection to his Stark heritage and the Old Gods of the North gives him the strength and resilience to withstand the Night King's powerful magic. Meanwhile, Bran Stark uses his powers as the Three-Eyed Raven to disrupt the Night King's control over the storm and the army of the dead.

With the storm subsiding and the Night King's power waning, Jon Snow delivers a final, decisive blow, shattering the Night King into a thousand shards of ice. The army of the dead collapses, and the blizzard dissipates, revealing the devastation left in its wake.

In this version of the final battle, the Night King's devastating new power amplifies the stakes and the intensity of the conflict, while also emphasizing the importance of unity, resilience, and the deep connection between the characters and the ancient magic of Westeros.

I will provide the answers to the questions and a cheat sheet summarizing the important concepts related to these questions. Note that some questions may be repeated, so I'll merge their answers in the cheat sheet.

Answers:

  1. Waterfall model: (a) Sequential phases of development, where each phase must be completed before the next can begin; (b) Less flexibility and adaptability, as changes are difficult to incorporate once a phase is completed.

  2. The git push command uploads local repository changes to a remote repository.

  3. A .gitignore file is used to specify files or directories that should not be tracked by the Git version control system.

Cheat Sheet:

  1. Motivation for Process Models

    • Software Process Model: Framework for organizing and managing software development activities.

  2. Overview of Process Models

    • Software Development Process Models:
      1. Waterfall model: Linear, sequential approach; each phase must be completed before moving to the next.
      2. Incremental model: a. Continuous Integration Model: Integrate and test code changes frequently. b. Multiple Releases: Deliver product in smaller, incremental releases.
      3. Spiral model: Iterative process, includes risk assessment and management.
      4. Rational Unified Process model: Iterative, use-case driven framework.
    • Entry and Exit Criteria: Define when a phase or task starts and ends.

  3. Agile Methodologies

    • Problems with "Traditional" Processes: Rigid, slow to respond to change.
    • Example Agile Methodologies: Scrum, Kanban, XP (eXtreme Programming).
    • XP's Core Values: Communication, simplicity, feedback, courage, respect.
    • XP's Fundamental Principles: Rapid feedback, assumption of simplicity, incremental change, embracing change, quality work.
    • XP's "Process": Iterative, incremental, test-driven approach.
    • Agile vs. Non-Agile: Agile focuses on flexibility, collaboration, and customer satisfaction.

  4. Test-Driven Development (TDD)

    • Write tests before writing code; refactor code for passing tests.

  5. Tool Support for Software Engineering

    • CASE: Computer-Aided Software Engineering tools to automate activities.
    • Tools for Software Engineering Activities: IDEs, version control systems, build tools, etc.

  6. Version Control Systems

    • Centralized vs. Distributed: Single server (e.g., SVN) vs. distributed repositories (e.g., Git).

  7. Git Basics

    • Basic git operations: clone, add, rm, commit, push, pull, status, blame, bisect, etc.
    • Merge conflicts: Resolve when multiple changes conflict.
    • Branches: Separate lines of development.
    • .gitignore: Ignore specified files/directories in version control.
    • Pull request: Request to merge changes from one branch to another.

  8. Process Models Recap

    • Selecting Process Models: Choose based on project needs, team size, and flexibility.

  9. Android

    • Android Software Stack: OS, middleware, and app layers.
    • Android Studio: Official IDE for Android development.
      • Uses Gradle build system by default.

  10. Android Basics

    • Learn by creating a basic app: Activities, Widgets, and UI components.

  11. Android SDK: Software Development Kit for Android app development.

  12. Android Project

    • Android Manifest file: XML file for app configuration and component declaration.
    • Resource files: Images, layouts, strings, etc.
    • Designing the UI: Use typical Android UI elements.
    • Android Activity: Represents a single screen with a user interface.
    • Callbacks: Methods called in response to events.

  13. Model-View-Controller: Separation of data, presentation, and user interaction logic.

  14. Event-Driven Programming

    • Event-Driven vs. Algorithm-Driven: Reacting to events vs. sequential execution.
    • GUI Event-Driven Programming: Handling GUI events with listeners and handlers.

  15. build.gradle Files

    • Project-level: Configuration for the entire project.
    • Module-level: Configuration for individual modules.

  16. Android Apps Lifecycle: Sequence of states an app goes through during execution.

  17. Activities and Intents

    • Using Android Intents: Start/stop activities, pass data, and return results.
    • Android Activity Lifecycle: States

an activity goes through during execution.

  1. Creating Activity Class: Extend AppCompatActivity and implement required methods.

  2. Example onCreate() Method

    • Elements in onCreate() Example: Set content view, initialize UI components, and set event listeners.

  3. Connecting UI and Activity: Use findViewById() to reference UI elements.

  4. Preparation for Requirement Engineering: Process to gather, analyze, and document software requirements.

  5. Major Requirements Engineering Activities

    • Requirements Elicitation: Collecting requirements from stakeholders.
    • Analysis: Requirements Categorization and Prioritization.
    • Requirements Definition/Prototyping/Review: Define, create prototypes, and review requirements.
    • Requirements Documentation: Detail requirements in a clear, concise, and organized manner.
    • Establishing Requirement Traceability: Track relationships between requirements and other artifacts.
    • Requirements Prototyping: Create a working model of the software.
    • Requirement Specification: Document detailed, complete, and consistent requirements.

  6. Review of Agile Model: Agile focuses on flexibility, collaboration, and customer satisfaction.

  7. Behavior-Driven Development (BDD): Agile approach using natural language scenarios to describe software behavior.

  8. User Stories for Requirements

    • User stories: Express application requirements in agile processes.
    • "Connextra" format: As a [role], I want [feature] so that [benefit].
    • "SMART" User Stories: Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound.
    • Acceptance Tests: Define criteria for user story completion.
    • Mapping User Stories to Acceptance Tests: Relate user stories to test scenarios.
    • Scenarios - Format: Given/When/Then.
    • Create Scenarios for User Stories.
    • Gherkin format: Structured language for defining scenarios.

  9. UI Requirements: Use "Lo-Fi" sketches, storyboards, and prototypes.

    • UI Sketches: Visual representation of UI elements.
    • UI Sketches and Wireframes: More detailed representation of UI design.
    • Storyboard: Sequence of UI sketches to represent user interaction.
    • From UI Sketches to Storyboards and Lo-Fi Prototype: Create low-fidelity prototypes.
    • Why "Lo-Fi" Storyboards and UI Sketches and Prototypes? Fast, cost-effective, and easy to modify.

  10. Measuring Productivity

    • Velocity: Measure of work completed in a given time period.
    • User Story Burndown Charts: Track progress on user stories over time.

  11. What is Software Quality?

    • Conforms to requirements (validation), fit to use (verification), quality assurance, and quality control.
    • Error-Detection Techniques: Testing, inspections/reviews, static analysis, formal methods.

  12. Error vs. Fault vs. Failure: Error (human action), Fault (incorrect program behavior), Failure (observable deviation from expected behavior).

  13. Limitation of Testing: Cannot prove the absence of faults, only their presence.

  14. What is Tested (Type of Tests): Unit, integration, system, acceptance, etc.

  15. Testing Methods: Glass-box (white-box), black-box, and combinations.

  16. Example Testing Methods: Equivalence Class Partitioning, Boundary Value Analysis, Path Analysis/Control Flow Testing, Combinations of Conditions, Guideline testing.

  17. Unit/Functional Testing: Test individual components or functions.

    • Assertion: Check if a condition is true.
    • Unit/Functional Testing Methods: Test specific functionality and expected outcomes.

  18. Test-Driven Development: Write tests before writing code, refactor code for passing tests.

  19. Common Test Coverage Levels: Method, call (entry/exit), statement, branch, and path coverages.

  20. Modified Condition/Decision Coverage (MCDC): Measure
Please continue where you left off.

1. Modified Condition/Decision Coverage (MCDC): Measure of the effectiveness of test cases in exercising different combinations of conditions in decision structures.

  2. Achieving Test Coverage: Design tests to cover various aspects of the code.

  3. Types of test execution approaches:

    • Regression Testing: Re-running tests to ensure changes didn't break existing functionality.
    • Continuous Integration Testing: Integrate and test code changes frequently.

  4. Inspections and Reviews:

    • Review: Examine artifacts to identify defects.
    • Walkthrough: Present artifacts to team members for feedback.
    • Software inspection: Formal process of reviewing artifacts.

  5. Inspections vs. Testing: Inspections identify defects in artifacts; testing identifies faults in code execution.

  6. Exercise: Design Test Cases: Create test cases based on requirements and test techniques.

  7. Equivalence Class Partitioning: Divide input domain into equivalent classes.

  8. Equivalence Class Partitioning: Heuristics: Use rules of thumb to identify classes.

  9. Test-Driven Development (TDD):

    • TDD High-Level Workflow: Write test, write code, refactor.
    • RED-GREEN-REFACTORING: Write a failing test, make it pass, improve code.

  10. Tools for TDD:

    • JUnit: Java testing framework.
    • JUnit Tests: Write and execute test cases.
    • Write a Simple Test Case: Define test methods with assertions.

  11. Types of Tests:

    • System or Acceptance Test: Verify the system meets requirements.
    • Integration/system testing: Test interactions between components.
    • Module or Functional Test: Test individual modules or functions.
    • Unit testing: Test individual units of code.

  12. Test Case and Running Test Case: Create test cases with expected outcomes and execute them.

  13. Components of a Test Case: Test inputs, expected outputs, and test procedure.

  14. Android UI Testing:

    • Espresso: Android UI testing framework.
    • ViewMatchers: Identify UI elements.
    • ViewActions: Perform actions on UI elements.
    • ViewAssertions: Verify UI element states.
    • Testing Scenarios with Espresso: Write and execute UI tests.
    • Basic Espresso Test: Create a simple test with onView, perform, and check.
    • Using Espresso: Preparation and Steps: Set up testing environment, write and run tests.
    • A Simple User Story: Define a user story for testing.
    • Testing a Scenario:
      • onView: Find a UI element.
      • perform: Execute an action on the UI element.
      • check: Verify the expected outcome.

1. Android Activity Lifecycle: Sequence of states an activity goes through as it runs, pauses, resumes, and stops.

  2. Creating Activity Class: Define a Java class that extends AppCompatActivity and overrides lifecycle methods.

  3. Example onCreate() Method: The method called when an activity is first created. It initializes UI and sets up data binding.

  4. Elements in onCreate() Example: setContentView() sets the layout, findViewById() retrieves UI elements, and listeners are set for UI events.

  5. Connecting UI and Activity: Use findViewById() to reference UI elements in the activity class and set up listeners for user interactions.

  6. Preparation for Requirement Engineering: Understand the problem domain, user needs, and constraints before starting requirements engineering.

  7. Major Requirements Engineering Activities:

    • Requirements Elicitation: Gather requirements from stakeholders.
    • Analysis: Requirements Categorization: Organize requirements into categories.
    • Analysis: Requirement Prioritization: Rank requirements by importance.
    • Requirements Definition/Prototyping/Review: Create, refine, and review requirement specifications.
    • Requirements Definitions/Documentation: Record requirements in a formal document.
    • Establishing Requirement Traceability: Track requirements from inception to implementation.
    • Requirements Prototyping: Create a prototype to validate and refine requirements.
    • Requirement Specification: Produce a detailed and precise description of requirements.

  8. Review of Agile Model: An iterative, incremental approach to software development that emphasizes flexibility and customer collaboration.

  9. Behavior-Driven Development (BDD): An Agile approach that encourages collaboration between developers, QA, and non-technical stakeholders in defining requirements and test scenarios.

  10. User Stories For Requirements:

    • User stories: Express application requirements in Agile processes.
    • Connextra format: As a [role], I want [feature] so that [benefit].
    • SMART User Stories: Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Time-bound.
    • Acceptance Tests: Define criteria for user story completion.
    • Mapping User stories to Acceptance Tests: Create test scenarios for each user story.
    • Scenarios - Format: Given/

1. Waterfall is a linear and sequential model, where each phase is completed before moving to the next one. Incremental model involves breaking the project into smaller increments and developing them iteratively, with each iteration adding functionality to the existing system.

  2. The Rational Unified Process (RUP) is an iterative and incremental software development process framework that provides guidelines, templates, and examples for all aspects of software development. It emphasizes the use of best practices, such as requirements management, iterative development, and risk management.

  3. Agile methodologies focus on flexibility, collaboration, and delivering working software quickly. They are designed to adapt to changing requirements, encourage close collaboration between developers and stakeholders, and prioritize customer satisfaction.

  4. XP's core values are communication, simplicity, feedback, and courage. Its fundamental principles include rapid feedback, assuming simplicity, embracing change, and continuously improving the design and code.

  5. Test-Driven Development (TDD) is an approach where developers write tests before writing the code. It helps ensure that the code meets the requirements, promotes clean and maintainable code, and helps catch errors early in the development process.

  6. Version Control Systems (VCS) track changes to files over time, allowing developers to collaborate, manage different versions, and revert to previous versions if needed. Centralized systems have a single central repository, while distributed systems have multiple repositories, allowing for greater flexibility and offline work.

  7. The Android Manifest file contains essential information about the app, such as its components (activities, services, etc.), permissions, and supported features. It's required for Android apps to run and be recognized by the Android system.

  8. Model-View-Controller (MVC) is an architectural pattern that separates an application into three components: Model (data and logic), View (user interface), and Controller (communication between Model and View). In Android, Activities and Fragments can act as Controllers, XML layouts as Views, and Java classes as Models.

  9. Event-driven programming is a paradigm where the flow of the program is determined by events, such as user input or system events. In GUI development, event-driven programming allows for better responsiveness and interactivity, with events triggering specific actions or responses.

  10. build.gradle files are configuration files for the Gradle build system in Android projects. Project-level files define global settings and dependencies, while module-level files define settings and dependencies specific to each module.

  11. The Android Activity Lifecycle describes the various states an activity can be in and the corresponding methods called by the system. These methods include onCreate(), onStart(), onResume(), onPause(), onStop(), and onDestroy().

  12. User Stories are short, simple descriptions of features from the user's perspective. In Behavior-Driven Development, user stories drive the creation of scenarios and tests, ensuring that the software meets user expectations and requirements.

  13. Equivalence Class Partitioning is a testing technique that divides input data into groups of equivalent values, reducing the number of test cases. For example, testing an age verification system, you could have three classes: under 18, 18-65, and over 65.

  14. Test execution approaches include regression testing, which checks for new issues after changes, and continuous integration testing, which involves running tests automatically when new code is integrated into the project.

  15. To create a JUnit test case in Java, you need to import the JUnit library, create a class that extends TestCase, and define test methods with the @Test annotation. Test methods typically use assert methods to check the expected outcome of the code being tested.

  16. Espresso is an Android UI testing framework that allows developers to write automated tests for user interactions. A basic Espresso test involves using onView() to find a view, perform() to perform an action on it, and check() to check a condition

1. In Test-Driven Development (TDD), Red-Green-Refactor is a process where developers first write a failing test (Red), then write code to make the test pass (Green), and finally refactor the code for improvements (Refactor).

  2. Software quality refers to how well software meets the requirements, is fit for its intended use, and is free from defects. Quality assurance and quality control techniques, such as testing, inspections, and reviews, help ensure software quality.

  3. Software validation ensures that the software meets the specified requirements, while software verification checks if the software is fit for its intended use. Validation answers the question "Are we building the right product?" while verification answers "Are we building the product right?"

  4. Android Intents are messaging objects that allow communication between components, such as starting another activity or requesting data from a content provider. An explicit Intent specifies the target component, while an implicit Intent relies on the Android system to find the appropriate component based on the specified action, data, and category.

1. The main difference between the Waterfall model and the Incremental model is that the Waterfall model is a linear sequential approach where each phase is completed before moving on to the next one, while the Incremental model divides the project into smaller parts, each part being developed and integrated iteratively.

  2. Continuous Integration in the Incremental model aims to ensure that newly developed code is constantly integrated with the existing codebase, reducing integration problems, and allowing for rapid feedback on potential issues.

  3. The main components of the Rational Unified Process (RUP) model are the four phases: Inception, Elaboration, Construction, and Transition, each with its own set of activities, artifacts, and milestones.

  4. The core values of Extreme Programming (XP) are simplicity, communication, feedback, and courage.

  5. Agile methodologies address the problems with traditional processes by emphasizing flexibility, collaboration, rapid iteration, and quick response to change.

  6. "Entry and exit criteria" in software development process models are the conditions that must be met for a project to enter or exit a specific phase. These criteria ensure that the required work is completed and objectives are met before moving on to the next phase.

  7. The primary goal of Behavior-Driven Development (BDD) is to bridge the communication gap between developers, testers, and business stakeholders, by creating a shared understanding of the expected behavior of the software.

  8. The Model-View-Controller (MVC) pattern separates the concerns of data management (Model), user interface (View), and control flow (Controller), making it easier to maintain, extend, and test the software.

  9. Centralized version control systems have a single, central repository, while distributed systems have multiple repositories, allowing developers to work independently and merge their changes later.

  10. The purpose of the Android Manifest file is to provide essential information about the app to the Android system, such as the app's components (activities, services, content providers), permissions, and features.

  11. The main components of the Android Software Stack are the Linux Kernel, Android Runtime (ART), native libraries, application framework, and applications.

  12. The main elements of a user story in the Connextra format are "As a [role], I want [feature] so that [benefit]." This format helps to clearly define the user's perspective, the desired functionality, and the reason for the feature.

  13. Equivalence Class Partitioning is a testing technique that divides the input data into groups of equivalent values (equivalence classes), so that testing one value from each group is sufficient to cover all possible input scenarios.

  14. Unit testing focuses on individual components (functions, classes), integration testing verifies the interaction between components, and system testing checks the entire application as a whole, including its performance, security, and usability.

  15. Storyboards and low-fidelity prototypes help in the requirements engineering process by providing a visual representation of the user interface and interactions, making it easier for stakeholders to understand and provide feedback on the design. Additionally, they are faster and cheaper to create and modify than high-fidelity prototypes.

1. Centralized version control systems have a single server that contains all the versioned files, while distributed version control systems have multiple repositories, with each user having their own repository.   2. The Gradle build system in Android Studio automates the process of building and packaging Android applications. It manages dependencies, compiles code, generates resources, and creates APK files for distribution.

  3. The Android activity lifecycle consists of various states that an activity goes through during its lifetime, such as onCreate, onStart, onResume, onPause, onStop, and onDestroy. Handling lifecycle events properly ensures that resources are managed efficiently and that the user experience remains consistent.

  4. To pass data between two Android activities, you can use intents with extras. You put the data as extras in the intent when starting the second activity and then retrieve the data from the intent in the second activity.

  5. Requirements elicitation is the process of gathering and collecting requirements from stakeholders, while requirements analysis involves organizing, categorizing, and prioritizing the collected requirements.

  6. Test-Driven Development (TDD) impacts the software development process by requiring developers to write tests before writing the actual code. This ensures that the code is correct and reliable from the start, leading to fewer bugs, improved maintainability, and easier refactoring.

  7. The .gitignore file in a Git repository specifies files and directories that should be ignored by Git when tracking changes. This helps in managing the codebase by excluding unnecessary files, such as build artifacts or temporary files, from version control.

  8. Requirement traceability is the ability to link requirements to their corresponding implementation, validation, and verification artifacts. It is important in software engineering to ensure that all requirements are implemented and tested, and to track the impact of requirement changes on the project.

  9. An Android content provider is a component that facilitates data sharing between applications. It allows one application to access and manipulate data from another application, providing a standardized interface for data access and management.

  10. Software quality assurance aims to ensure that the software development process and its products meet the required quality standards, while quality control focuses on identifying defects in the final product. Both contribute to the overall quality of the software.

  11. White-box testing involves testing the internal structure and logic of the code, while black-box testing focuses on the functionality of the software without knowledge of its internal workings. White-box testing examples include unit testing and code coverage analysis, while black-box testing examples include system testing and user acceptance testing.

  12. Storyboards and low-fidelity prototypes are used in the requirements engineering process to visualize and communicate the user interface and interactions. They help stakeholders understand the proposed design and provide feedback early in the development process, reducing the risk of costly changes later on.

  13.   14. The Rational Unified Process (RUP) model is an iterative software development process that consists of four phases: Inception, Elaboration, Construction, and Transition. Each phase has specific goals and deliverables, and the process emphasizes continuous risk management and stakeholder involvement.

  15. The key advantages of Agile methodologies over traditional plan-and-document process models include better adaptability to change, faster delivery of working software, improved collaboration between team members, and a focus on customer satisfaction and continuous improvement.
